page.title: 08VILLAGE LIFE : WALL.
page.content: Wall village was once a Roman settlement and has a museum of Roman artefacts and an excavated bath house which attracts many visitors. The village school closed in 1978 and the younger children now have to travel to nearby Shenstone, the older children attending school in Lichfield. At the top of the hill stands the church of St.John the Baptist. There are no shops, one public house, "The Trooper", and a very limited bus service. Manor Farmhouse was built in 1669 and is situated at the top of the village. Centre of activity is the village Hall which is used for snooker and darts, evening classes, weekly Whist Drives, Wedding receptions, parties and the Women's Institute monthly meetings In 1982 seven old peoples' bungalows were built opposite the village green.
